meanings.definition: To remove from a seat or position of authority.
meanings.sent1: The teacher had to disseat the student from the principal's chair.
meanings.sent2: The committee decided to disseat the corrupt official from his position.
meanings.sent3: The cat tried to disseat the dog from its favorite spot on the couch.
meanings.sent4: The storm threatened to disseat the reigning champion from his throne.
meanings.sent5: The sudden revelation would disseat the king from his complacency.

meanings.definition: To cause to feel uneasy or uncomfortable.
meanings.sent1: The eerie silence began to disseat the nervous child.
meanings.sent2: The awkward situation started to disseat everyone in the room.
meanings.sent3: The unexpected compliment managed to disseat her usual calm demeanor.
meanings.sent4: The strange noise outside seemed to disseat the peace of the night.
meanings.sent5: The unsettling news would disseat even the most composed individual.

meanings.sent1: The rebels planned to disseat the tyrant ruler from power.
meanings.sent2: The opposition party aimed to disseat the current government in the election.
meanings.sent3: The mischievous plan to disseat the class president was foiled.
meanings.sent4: The unexpected turn of events threatened to disseat the established order.
meanings.sent5: The uprising sought to disseat the oppressive regime once and for all.
